CWE-302.description: The authentication scheme or implementation uses key data elements that are assumed to be immutable, but can be controlled or modified by the attacker.

CWE-304.name: Missing Critical Step in Authentication
CWE-304.description: The product implements an authentication technique, but it skips a step that weakens the technique.

CWE-31.name: Path Traversal: 'dir\..\..\filename'
CWE-31.description: The product uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory, but it does not properly neutralize 'dir\..\..\filename' (multiple internal backslash dot dot) sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory.

CWE-311.name: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data
CWE-311.description: The product does not encrypt sensitive or critical information before storage or transmission.

CWE-313.name: Cleartext Storage in a File or on Disk
CWE-313.description: The product stores sensitive information in cleartext in a file, or on disk.

CWE-314.name: Cleartext Storage in the Registry
CWE-314.description: The product stores sensitive information in cleartext in the registry.

CWE-315.name: Cleartext Storage of Sensitive Information in a Cookie
CWE-315.description: The product stores sensitive information in cleartext in a cookie.

CWE-316.name: Cleartext Storage of Sensitive Information in Memory
CWE-316.description: The product stores sensitive information in cleartext in memory.

CWE-317.name: Cleartext Storage of Sensitive Information in GUI
CWE-317.description: The product stores sensitive information in cleartext within the GUI.

CWE-318.name: Cleartext Storage of Sensitive Information in Executable
CWE-318.description: The product stores sensitive information in cleartext in an executable.

CWE-32.name: Path Traversal: '...' (Triple Dot)
CWE-32.description: The product uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory, but it does not properly neutralize '...' (triple dot) sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory.

CWE-321.name: Use of Hard-coded Cryptographic Key
CWE-321.description: The product uses a hard-coded, unchangeable cryptographic key.

CWE-326.name: Inadequate Encryption Strength
CWE-326.description: The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required.

CWE-327.name: Use of a Broken or Risky Cryptographic Algorithm
CWE-327.description: The product uses a broken or risky cryptographic algorithm or protocol.

CWE-329.name: Generation of Predictable IV with CBC Mode
CWE-329.description: The product generates and uses a predictable initialization Vector (IV) with Cipher Block Chaining (CBC) Mode, which causes algorithms to be susceptible to dictionary attacks when they are encrypted under the same key.

CWE-33.name: Path Traversal: '....' (Multiple Dot)
CWE-33.description: The product uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory, but it does not properly neutralize '....' (multiple dot) sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory.

CWE-330.name: Use of Insufficiently Random Values
CWE-330.description: The product uses insufficiently random numbers or values in a security context that depends on unpredictable numbers.

CWE-332.name: Insufficient Entropy in PRNG
CWE-332.description: The lack of entropy available for, or used by, a Pseudo-Random Number Generator (PRNG) can be a stability and security threat.

CWE-333.name: Improper Handling of Insufficient Entropy in TRNG
CWE-333.description: True random number generators (TRNG) generally have a limited source of entropy and therefore can fail or block.

CWE-336.name: Same Seed in Pseudo-Random Number Generator (PRNG)
CWE-336.description: A Pseudo-Random Number Generator (PRNG) uses the same seed each time the product is initialized.

CWE-337.name: Predictable Seed in Pseudo-Random Number Generator (PRNG)
CWE-337.description: A Pseudo-Random Number Generator (PRNG) is initialized from a predictable seed, such as the process ID or system time.

CWE-339.name: Small Seed Space in PRNG
CWE-339.description: A Pseudo-Random Number Generator (PRNG) uses a relatively small seed space, which makes it more susceptible to brute force attacks.

CWE-34.name: Path Traversal: '....//'
CWE-34.description: The product uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory, but it does not properly neutralize '....//' (doubled dot dot slash) sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory.

CWE-340.name: Generation of Predictable Numbers or Identifiers
CWE-340.description: The product uses a scheme that generates numbers or identifiers that are more predictable than required.

CWE-345.name: Insufficient Verification of Data Authenticity
CWE-345.description: The product does not sufficiently verify the origin or authenticity of data, in a way that causes it to accept invalid data.

CWE-35.name: Path Traversal: '.../...//'
CWE-35.description: The product uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory, but it does not properly neutralize '.../...//' (doubled triple dot slash) sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory.

CWE-350.name: Reliance on Reverse DNS Resolution for a Security-Critical Action
CWE-350.description: The product performs reverse DNS resolution on an IP address to obtain the hostname and make a security decision, but it does not properly ensure that the IP address is truly associated with the hostname.

CWE-352.name: Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF)
CWE-352.description: The web application does not, or cannot, sufficiently verify whether a request was intentionally provided by the user who sent the request, which could have originated from an unauthorized actor.

CWE-36.name: Absolute Path Traversal
CWE-36.description: The product uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory, but it does not properly neutralize absolute path sequences such as "/abs/path" that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory.

CWE-362.name: Concurrent Execution using Shared Resource with Improper Synchronization ('Race Condition')
CWE-362.description: The product contains a concurrent code sequence that requires temporary, exclusive access to a shared resource, but a timing window exists in which the shared resource can be modified by another code sequence operating concurrently.

CWE-363.name: Race Condition Enabling Link Following
CWE-363.description: The product checks the status of a file or directory before accessing it, which produces a race condition in which the file can be replaced with a link before the access is performed, causing the product to access the wrong file.

CWE-37.name: Path Traversal: '/absolute/pathname/here'
CWE-37.description: The product accepts input in the form of a slash absolute path ('/absolute/pathname/here') without appropriate validation, which can allow an attacker to traverse the file system to unintended locations or access arbitrary files.

CWE-370.name: Missing Check for Certificate Revocation after Initial Check
CWE-370.description: The product does not check the revocation status of a certificate after its initial revocation check, which can cause the product to perform privileged actions even after the certificate is revoked at a later time.

CWE-377.name: Insecure Temporary File
CWE-377.description: Creating and using insecure temporary files can leave application and system data vulnerable to attack.

CWE-38.name: Path Traversal: '\absolute\pathname\here'
CWE-38.description: The product accepts input in the form of a backslash absolute path ('\absolute\pathname\here') without appropriate validation, which can allow an attacker to traverse the file system to unintended locations or access arbitrary files.

CWE-382.name: J2EE Bad Practices: Use of System.exit()
CWE-382.description: A J2EE application uses System.exit(), which also shuts down its container.

CWE-383.name: J2EE Bad Practices: Direct Use of Threads
CWE-383.description: Thread management in a Web application is forbidden in some circumstances and is always highly error prone.

CWE-384.name: Session Fixation
CWE-384.description: Authenticating a user, or otherwise establishing a new user session, without invalidating any existing session identifier gives an attacker the opportunity to steal authenticated sessions.

CWE-39.name: Path Traversal: 'C:dirname'
CWE-39.description: The product accepts input that contains a drive letter or Windows volume letter ('C:dirname') that potentially redirects access to an unintended location or arbitrary file.

CWE-40.name: Path Traversal: '\\UNC\share\name\' (Windows UNC Share)
CWE-40.description: The product accepts input that identifies a Windows UNC share ('\\UNC\share\name') that potentially redirects access to an unintended location or arbitrary file.

CWE-400.name: Uncontrolled Resource Consumption
CWE-400.description: The product does not properly control the allocation and maintenance of a limited resource.

CWE-401.name: Missing Release of Memory after Effective Lifetime
CWE-401.description: The product does not sufficiently track and release allocated memory after it has been used, making the memory unavailable for reallocation and reuse.

CWE-402.name: Transmission of Private Resources into a New Sphere ('Resource Leak')
CWE-402.description: The product makes resources available to untrusted parties when those resources are only intended to be accessed by the product.

CWE-404.name: Improper Resource Shutdown or Release
CWE-404.description: The product does not release or incorrectly releases a resource before it is made available for re-use.

CWE-405.name: Asymmetric Resource Consumption (Amplification)
CWE-405.description: The product does not properly control situations in which an adversary can cause the product to consume or produce excessive resources without requiring the adversary to invest equivalent work or otherwise prove authorization, i.e., the adversary's influence is "asymmetric."

CWE-406.name: Insufficient Control of Network Message Volume (Network Amplification)
CWE-406.description: The product does not sufficiently monitor or control transmitted network traffic volume, so that an actor can cause the product to transmit more traffic than should be allowed for that actor.

CWE-407.name: Inefficient Algorithmic Complexity
CWE-407.description: An algorithm in a product has an inefficient worst-case computational complexity that may be detrimental to system performance and can be triggered by an attacker, typically using crafted manipulations that ensure that the worst case is being reached.

CWE-415.name: Double Free
CWE-415.description: The product calls free() twice on the same memory address.

CWE-416.name: Use After Free
CWE-416.description: The product reuses or references memory after it has been freed. At some point afterward, the memory may be allocated again and saved in another pointer, while the original pointer references a location somewhere within the new allocation. Any operations using the original pointer are no longer valid because the memory "belongs" to the code that operates on the new pointer.

CWE-42.name: Path Equivalence: 'filename.' (Trailing Dot)
CWE-42.description: The product accepts path input in the form of trailing dot ('filedir.') without appropriate validation, which can lead to ambiguous path resolution and allow an attacker to traverse the file system to unintended locations or access arbitrary files.

CWE-422.name: Unprotected Windows Messaging Channel ('Shatter')
CWE-422.description: The product does not properly verify the source of a message in the Windows Messaging System while running at elevated privileges, creating an alternate channel through which an attacker can directly send a message to the product.

CWE-424.name: Improper Protection of Alternate Path
CWE-424.description: The product does not sufficiently protect all possible paths that a user can take to access restricted functionality or resources.

CWE-43.name: Path Equivalence: 'filename....' (Multiple Trailing Dot)
CWE-43.description: The product accepts path input in the form of multiple trailing dot ('filedir....') without appropriate validation, which can lead to ambiguous path resolution and allow an attacker to traverse the file system to unintended locations or access arbitrary files.

CWE-432.name: Dangerous Signal Handler not Disabled During Sensitive Operations
CWE-432.description: The product uses a signal handler that shares state with other signal handlers, but it does not properly mask or prevent those signal handlers from being invoked while the original signal handler is still running.

CWE-433.name: Unparsed Raw Web Content Delivery
CWE-433.description: The product stores raw content or supporting code under the web document root with an extension that is not specifically handled by the server.

CWE-435.name: Improper Interaction Between Multiple Correctly-Behaving Entities
CWE-435.description: An interaction error occurs when two entities have correct behavior when running independently of each other, but when they are integrated as components in a larger system or process, they introduce incorrect behaviors that may cause resultant weaknesses.

CWE-436.name: Interpretation Conflict
CWE-436.description: Product A handles inputs or steps differently than Product B, which causes A to perform incorrect actions based on its perception of B's state.

CWE-44.name: Path Equivalence: 'file.name' (Internal Dot)
CWE-44.description: The product accepts path input in the form of internal dot ('file.ordir') without appropriate validation, which can lead to ambiguous path resolution and allow an attacker to traverse the file system to unintended locations or access arbitrary files.

CWE-446.name: UI Discrepancy for Security Feature
CWE-446.description: The user interface does not correctly enable or configure a security feature, but the interface provides feedback that causes the user to believe that the feature is in a secure state.

CWE-45.name: Path Equivalence: 'file...name' (Multiple Internal Dot)
CWE-45.description: The product accepts path input in the form of multiple internal dot ('file...dir') without appropriate validation, which can lead to ambiguous path resolution and allow an attacker to traverse the file system to unintended locations or access arbitrary files.

CWE-450.name: Multiple Interpretations of UI Input
CWE-450.description: The UI has multiple interpretations of user input but does not prompt the user when it selects the less secure interpretation.

CWE-451.name: User Interface (UI) Misrepresentation of Critical Information
CWE-451.description: The user interface (UI) does not properly represent critical information to the user, allowing the information - or its source - to be obscured or spoofed. This is often a component in phishing attacks.

CWE-453.name: Insecure Default Variable Initialization
CWE-453.description: The product, by default, initializes an internal variable with an insecure or less secure value than is possible.

CWE-456.name: Missing Initialization of a Variable
CWE-456.description: The product does not initialize critical variables, which causes the execution environment to use unexpected values.

CWE-457.name: Use of Uninitialized Variable
CWE-457.description: The code uses a variable that has not been initialized, leading to unpredictable or unintended results.

CWE-46.name: Path Equivalence: 'filename ' (Trailing Space)
CWE-46.description: The product accepts path input in the form of trailing space ('filedir ') without appropriate validation, which can lead to ambiguous path resolution and allow an attacker to traverse the file system to unintended locations or access arbitrary files.

CWE-460.name: Improper Cleanup on Thrown Exception
CWE-460.description: The product does not clean up its state or incorrectly cleans up its state when an exception is thrown, leading to unexpected state or control flow.

CWE-462.name: Duplicate Key in Associative List (Alist)
CWE-462.description: Duplicate keys in associative lists can lead to non-unique keys being mistaken for an error.

CWE-467.name: Use of sizeof() on a Pointer Type
CWE-467.description: The code calls sizeof() on a pointer type, which can be an incorrect calculation if the programmer intended to determine the size of the data that is being pointed to.

CWE-47.name: Path Equivalence: ' filename' (Leading Space)
CWE-47.description: The product accepts path input in the form of leading space (' filedir') without appropriate validation, which can lead to ambiguous path resolution and allow an attacker to traverse the file system to unintended locations or access arbitrary files.

CWE-471.name: Modification of Assumed-Immutable Data (MAID)
CWE-471.description: The product does not properly protect an assumed-immutable element from being modified by an attacker.

CWE-473.name: PHP External Variable Modification
CWE-473.description: A PHP application does not properly protect against the modification of variables from external sources, such as query parameters or cookies. This can expose the application to numerous weaknesses that would not exist otherwise.

CWE-479.name: Signal Handler Use of a Non-reentrant Function
CWE-479.description: The product defines a signal handler that calls a non-reentrant function.

CWE-48.name: Path Equivalence: 'file name' (Internal Whitespace)
CWE-48.description: The product accepts path input in the form of internal space ('file(SPACE)name') without appropriate validation, which can lead to ambiguous path resolution and allow an attacker to traverse the file system to unintended locations or access arbitrary files.

CWE-481.name: Assigning instead of Comparing
CWE-481.description: The code uses an operator for assignment when the intention was to perform a comparison.

CWE-482.name: Comparing instead of Assigning
CWE-482.description: The code uses an operator for comparison when the intention was to perform an assignment.

CWE-486.name: Comparison of Classes by Name
CWE-486.description: The product compares classes by name, which can cause it to use the wrong class when multiple classes can have the same name.

CWE-49.name: Path Equivalence: 'filename/' (Trailing Slash)
CWE-49.description: The product accepts path input in the form of trailing slash ('filedir/') without appropriate validation, which can lead to ambiguous path resolution and allow an attacker to traverse the file system to unintended locations or access arbitrary files.

CWE-491.name: Public cloneable() Method Without Final ('Object Hijack')
CWE-491.description: A class has a cloneable() method that is not declared final, which allows an object to be created without calling the constructor. This can cause the object to be in an unexpected state.

CWE-492.name: Use of Inner Class Containing Sensitive Data
CWE-492.description: Inner classes are translated into classes that are accessible at package scope and may expose code that the programmer intended to keep private to attackers.

CWE-493.name: Critical Public Variable Without Final Modifier
CWE-493.description: The product has a critical public variable that is not final, which allows the variable to be modified to contain unexpected values.

CWE-495.name: Private Data Structure Returned From A Public Method
CWE-495.description: The product has a method that is declared public, but returns a reference to a private data structure, which could then be modified in unexpected ways.

CWE-496.name: Public Data Assigned to Private Array-Typed Field
CWE-496.description: Assigning public data to a private array is equivalent to giving public access to the array.

CWE-498.name: Cloneable Class Containing Sensitive Information
CWE-498.description: The code contains a class with sensitive data, but the class is cloneable. The data can then be accessed by cloning the class.

CWE-499.name: Serializable Class Containing Sensitive Data
CWE-499.description: The code contains a class with sensitive data, but the class does not explicitly deny serialization. The data can be accessed by serializing the class through another class.

CWE-5.name: J2EE Misconfiguration: Data Transmission Without Encryption
CWE-5.description: Information sent over a network can be compromised while in transit. An attacker may be able to read or modify the contents if the data are sent in plaintext or are weakly encrypted.

CWE-50.name: Path Equivalence: '//multiple/leading/slash'
CWE-50.description: The product accepts path input in the form of multiple leading slash ('//multiple/leading/slash') without appropriate validation, which can lead to ambiguous path resolution and allow an attacker to traverse the file system to unintended locations or access arbitrary files.

CWE-500.name: Public Static Field Not Marked Final
CWE-500.description: An object contains a public static field that is not marked final, which might allow it to be modified in unexpected ways.

CWE-506.name: Embedded Malicious Code
CWE-506.description: The product contains code that appears to be malicious in nature.

CWE-507.name: Trojan Horse
CWE-507.description: The product appears to contain benign or useful functionality, but it also contains code that is hidden from normal operation that violates the intended security policy of the user or the system administrator.

CWE-508.name: Non-Replicating Malicious Code
CWE-508.description: Non-replicating malicious code only resides on the target system or product that is attacked; it does not attempt to spread to other systems.

CWE-509.name: Replicating Malicious Code (Virus or Worm)
CWE-509.description: Replicating malicious code, including viruses and worms, will attempt to attack other systems once it has successfully compromised the target system or the product.

CWE-51.name: Path Equivalence: '/multiple//internal/slash'
CWE-51.description: The product accepts path input in the form of multiple internal slash ('/multiple//internal/slash/') without appropriate validation, which can lead to ambiguous path resolution and allow an attacker to traverse the file system to unintended locations or access arbitrary files.

CWE-510.name: Trapdoor
CWE-510.description: A trapdoor is a hidden piece of code that responds to a special input, allowing its user access to resources without passing through the normal security enforcement mechanism.

CWE-511.name: Logic/Time Bomb
CWE-511.description: The product contains code that is designed to disrupt the legitimate operation of the product (or its environment) when a certain time passes, or when a certain logical condition is met.

CWE-512.name: Spyware
CWE-512.description: The product collects personally identifiable information about a human user or the user's activities, but the product accesses this information using other resources besides itself, and it does not require that user's explicit approval or direct input into the product.

CWE-514.name: Covert Channel
CWE-514.description: A covert channel is a path that can be used to transfer information in a way not intended by the system's designers.

CWE-52.name: Path Equivalence: '/multiple/trailing/slash//'
CWE-52.description: The product accepts path input in the form of multiple trailing slash ('/multiple/trailing/slash//') without appropriate validation, which can lead to ambiguous path resolution and allow an attacker to traverse the file system to unintended locations or access arbitrary files.

CWE-520.name: .NET Misconfiguration: Use of Impersonation
CWE-520.description: Allowing a .NET application to run at potentially escalated levels of access to the underlying operating and file systems can be dangerous and result in various forms of attacks.

CWE-522.name: Insufficiently Protected Credentials
CWE-522.description: The product transmits or stores authentication credentials, but it uses an insecure method that is susceptible to unauthorized interception and/or retrieval.

CWE-525.name: Use of Web Browser Cache Containing Sensitive Information
CWE-525.description: The web application does not use an appropriate caching policy that specifies the extent to which each web page and associated form fields should be cached.

CWE-526.name: Cleartext Storage of Sensitive Information in an Environment Variable
CWE-526.description: The product uses an environment variable to store unencrypted sensitive information.

CWE-527.name: Exposure of Version-Control Repository to an Unauthorized Control Sphere
CWE-527.description: The product stores a CVS, git, or other repository in a directory, archive, or other resource that is stored, transferred, or otherwise made accessible to unauthorized actors.

CWE-528.name: Exposure of Core Dump File to an Unauthorized Control Sphere
CWE-528.description: The product generates a core dump file in a directory, archive, or other resource that is stored, transferred, or otherwise made accessible to unauthorized actors.

CWE-529.name: Exposure of Access Control List Files to an Unauthorized Control Sphere
CWE-529.description: The product stores access control list files in a directory or other container that is accessible to actors outside of the intended control sphere.

CWE-53.name: Path Equivalence: '\multiple\\internal\backslash'
CWE-53.description: The product accepts path input in the form of multiple internal backslash ('\multiple\trailing\\slash') without appropriate validation, which can lead to ambiguous path resolution and allow an attacker to traverse the file system to unintended locations or access arbitrary files.

CWE-530.name: Exposure of Backup File to an Unauthorized Control Sphere
CWE-530.description: A backup file is stored in a directory or archive that is made accessible to unauthorized actors.

CWE-531.name: Inclusion of Sensitive Information in Test Code
CWE-531.description: Accessible test applications can pose a variety of security risks. Since developers or administrators rarely consider that someone besides themselves would even know about the existence of these applications, it is common for them to contain sensitive information or functions.

CWE-532.name: Insertion of Sensitive Information into Log File
CWE-532.description: The product writes sensitive information to a log file.

CWE-535.name: Exposure of Information Through Shell Error Message
CWE-535.description: A command shell error message indicates that there exists an unhandled exception in the web application code. In many cases, an attacker can leverage the conditions that cause these errors in order to gain unauthorized access to the system.

CWE-536.name: Servlet Runtime Error Message Containing Sensitive Information
CWE-536.description: A servlet error message indicates that there exists an unhandled exception in the web application code and may provide useful information to an attacker.

CWE-537.name: Java Runtime Error Message Containing Sensitive Information
CWE-537.description: In many cases, an attacker can leverage the conditions that cause unhandled exception errors in order to gain unauthorized access to the system.

CWE-539.name: Use of Persistent Cookies Containing Sensitive Information
CWE-539.description: The web application uses persistent cookies, but the cookies contain sensitive information.

CWE-54.name: Path Equivalence: 'filedir\' (Trailing Backslash)
CWE-54.description: The product accepts path input in the form of trailing backslash ('filedir\') without appropriate validation, which can lead to ambiguous path resolution and allow an attacker to traverse the file system to unintended locations or access arbitrary files.

CWE-540.name: Inclusion of Sensitive Information in Source Code
CWE-540.description: Source code on a web server or repository often contains sensitive information and should generally not be accessible to users.

CWE-541.name: Inclusion of Sensitive Information in an Include File
CWE-541.description: If an include file source is accessible, the file can contain usernames and passwords, as well as sensitive information pertaining to the application and system.

CWE-543.name: Use of Singleton Pattern Without Synchronization in a Multithreaded Context
CWE-543.description: The product uses the singleton pattern when creating a resource within a multithreaded environment.

CWE-546.name: Suspicious Comment
CWE-546.description: The code contains comments that suggest the presence of bugs, incomplete functionality, or weaknesses.

CWE-548.name: Exposure of Information Through Directory Listing
CWE-548.description: The product inappropriately exposes a directory listing with an index of all the resources located inside of the directory.

CWE-55.name: Path Equivalence: '/./' (Single Dot Directory)
CWE-55.description: The product accepts path input in the form of single dot directory exploit ('/./') without appropriate validation, which can lead to ambiguous path resolution and allow an attacker to traverse the file system to unintended locations or access arbitrary files.

CWE-550.name: Server-generated Error Message Containing Sensitive Information
CWE-550.description: Certain conditions, such as network failure, will cause a server error message to be displayed.

CWE-553.name: Command Shell in Externally Accessible Directory
CWE-553.description: A possible shell file exists in /cgi-bin/ or other accessible directories. This is extremely dangerous and can be used by an attacker to execute commands on the web server.

CWE-554.name: ASP.NET Misconfiguration: Not Using Input Validation Framework
CWE-554.description: The ASP.NET application does not use an input validation framework.

CWE-555.name: J2EE Misconfiguration: Plaintext Password in Configuration File
CWE-555.description: The J2EE application stores a plaintext password in a configuration file.

CWE-556.name: ASP.NET Misconfiguration: Use of Identity Impersonation
CWE-556.description: Configuring an ASP.NET application to run with impersonated credentials may give the application unnecessary privileges.

CWE-558.name: Use of getlogin() in Multithreaded Application
CWE-558.description: The product uses the getlogin() function in a multithreaded context, potentially causing it to return incorrect values.

CWE-56.name: Path Equivalence: 'filedir*' (Wildcard)
CWE-56.description: The product accepts path input in the form of asterisk wildcard ('filedir*') without appropriate validation, which can lead to ambiguous path resolution and allow an attacker to traverse the file system to unintended locations or access arbitrary files.

CWE-560.name: Use of umask() with chmod-style Argument
CWE-560.description: The product calls umask() with an incorrect argument that is specified as if it is an argument to chmod().

CWE-564.name: SQL Injection: Hibernate
CWE-564.description: Using Hibernate to execute a dynamic SQL statement built with user-controlled input can allow an attacker to modify the statement's meaning or to execute arbitrary SQL commands.

CWE-566.name: Authorization Bypass Through User-Controlled SQL Primary Key
CWE-566.description: The product uses a database table that includes records that should not be accessible to an actor, but it executes a SQL statement with a primary key that can be controlled by that actor.

CWE-567.name: Unsynchronized Access to Shared Data in a Multithreaded Context
CWE-567.description: The product does not properly synchronize shared data, such as static variables across threads, which can lead to undefined behavior and unpredictable data changes.

CWE-568.name: finalize() Method Without super.finalize()
CWE-568.description: The product contains a finalize() method that does not call super.finalize().

CWE-57.name: Path Equivalence: 'fakedir/../realdir/filename'
CWE-57.description: The product contains protection mechanisms to restrict access to 'realdir/filename', but it constructs pathnames using external input in the form of 'fakedir/../realdir/filename' that are not handled by those mechanisms. This allows attackers to perform unauthorized actions against the targeted file.

CWE-572.name: Call to Thread run() instead of start()
CWE-572.description: The product calls a thread's run() method instead of calling start(), which causes the code to run in the thread of the caller instead of the callee.

CWE-573.name: Improper Following of Specification by Caller
CWE-573.description: The product does not follow or incorrectly follows the specifications as required by the implementation language, environment, framework, protocol, or platform.

CWE-574.name: EJB Bad Practices: Use of Synchronization Primitives
CWE-574.description: The product violates the Enterprise JavaBeans (EJB) specification by using thread synchronization primitives.

CWE-575.name: EJB Bad Practices: Use of AWT Swing
CWE-575.description: The product violates the Enterprise JavaBeans (EJB) specification by using AWT/Swing.

CWE-576.name: EJB Bad Practices: Use of Java I/O
CWE-576.description: The product violates the Enterprise JavaBeans (EJB) specification by using the java.io package.

CWE-577.name: EJB Bad Practices: Use of Sockets
CWE-577.description: The product violates the Enterprise JavaBeans (EJB) specification by using sockets.

CWE-578.name: EJB Bad Practices: Use of Class Loader
CWE-578.description: The product violates the Enterprise JavaBeans (EJB) specification by using the class loader.

CWE-579.name: J2EE Bad Practices: Non-serializable Object Stored in Session
CWE-579.description: The product stores a non-serializable object as an HttpSession attribute, which can hurt reliability.

CWE-58.name: Path Equivalence: Windows 8.3 Filename
CWE-58.description: The product contains a protection mechanism that restricts access to a long filename on a Windows operating system, but it does not properly restrict access to the equivalent short "8.3" filename.

CWE-582.name: Array Declared Public, Final, and Static
CWE-582.description: The product declares an array public, final, and static, which is not sufficient to prevent the array's contents from being modified.

CWE-583.name: finalize() Method Declared Public
CWE-583.description: The product violates secure coding principles for mobile code by declaring a finalize() method public.

CWE-585.name: Empty Synchronized Block
CWE-585.description: The product contains an empty synchronized block.

CWE-588.name: Attempt to Access Child of a Non-structure Pointer
CWE-588.description: Casting a non-structure type to a structure type and accessing a field can lead to memory access errors or data corruption.

CWE-589.name: Call to Non-ubiquitous API
CWE-589.description: The product uses an API function that does not exist on all versions of the target platform. This could cause portability problems or inconsistencies that allow denial of service or other consequences.

CWE-590.name: Free of Memory not on the Heap
CWE-590.description: The product calls free() on a pointer to memory that was not allocated using associated heap allocation functions such as malloc(), calloc(), or realloc().

CWE-591.name: Sensitive Data Storage in Improperly Locked Memory
CWE-591.description: The product stores sensitive data in memory that is not locked, or that has been incorrectly locked, which might cause the memory to be written to swap files on disk by the virtual memory manager. This can make the data more accessible to external actors.

CWE-593.name: Authentication Bypass: OpenSSL CTX Object Modified after SSL Objects are Created
CWE-593.description: The product modifies the SSL context after connection creation has begun.

CWE-594.name: J2EE Framework: Saving Unserializable Objects to Disk
CWE-594.description: When the J2EE container attempts to write unserializable objects to disk there is no guarantee that the process will complete successfully.

CWE-595.name: Comparison of Object References Instead of Object Contents
CWE-595.description: The product compares object references instead of the contents of the objects themselves, preventing it from detecting equivalent objects.

CWE-597.name: Use of Wrong Operator in String Comparison
CWE-597.description: The product uses the wrong operator when comparing a string, such as using "==" when the .equals() method should be used instead.

CWE-598.name: Use of GET Request Method With Sensitive Query Strings
CWE-598.description: The web application uses the HTTP GET method to process a request and includes sensitive information in the query string of that request.

CWE-599.name: Missing Validation of OpenSSL Certificate
CWE-599.description: The product uses OpenSSL and trusts or uses a certificate without using the SSL_get_verify_result() function to ensure that the certificate satisfies all necessary security requirements.

CWE-6.name: J2EE Misconfiguration: Insufficient Session-ID Length
CWE-6.description: The J2EE application is configured to use an insufficient session ID length.

CWE-600.name: Uncaught Exception in Servlet
CWE-600.description: The Servlet does not catch all exceptions, which may reveal sensitive debugging information.

CWE-602.name: Client-Side Enforcement of Server-Side Security
CWE-602.description: The product is composed of a server that relies on the client to implement a mechanism that is intended to protect the server.

CWE-607.name: Public Static Final Field References Mutable Object
CWE-607.description: A public or protected static final field references a mutable object, which allows the object to be changed by malicious code, or accidentally from another package.

CWE-608.name: Struts: Non-private Field in ActionForm Class
CWE-608.description: An ActionForm class contains a field that has not been declared private, which can be accessed without using a setter or getter.

CWE-61.name: UNIX Symbolic Link (Symlink) Following
CWE-61.description: The product, when opening a file or directory, does not sufficiently account for when the file is a symbolic link that resolves to a target outside of the intended control sphere. This could allow an attacker to cause the product to operate on unauthorized files.

CWE-610.name: Externally Controlled Reference to a Resource in Another Sphere
CWE-610.description: The product uses an externally controlled name or reference that resolves to a resource that is outside of the intended control sphere.

CWE-612.name: Improper Authorization of Index Containing Sensitive Information
CWE-612.description: The product creates a search index of private or sensitive documents, but it does not properly limit index access to actors who are authorized to see the original information.

CWE-614.name: Sensitive Cookie in HTTPS Session Without 'Secure' Attribute
CWE-614.description: The Secure attribute for sensitive cookies in HTTPS sessions is not set.

CWE-615.name: Inclusion of Sensitive Information in Source Code Comments
CWE-615.description: While adding general comments is very useful, some programmers tend to leave important data, such as: filenames related to the web application, old links or links which were not meant to be browsed by users, old code fragments, etc.

CWE-616.name: Incomplete Identification of Uploaded File Variables (PHP)
CWE-616.description: The PHP application uses an old method for processing uploaded files by referencing the four global variables that are set for each file (e.g. $varname, $varname_size, $varname_name, $varname_type). These variables could be overwritten by attackers, causing the application to process unauthorized files.

CWE-62.name: UNIX Hard Link
CWE-62.description: The product, when opening a file or directory, does not sufficiently account for when the name is associated with a hard link to a target that is outside of the intended control sphere. This could allow an attacker to cause the product to operate on unauthorized files.

CWE-621.name: Variable Extraction Error
CWE-621.description: The product uses external input to determine the names of variables into which information is extracted, without verifying that the names of the specified variables are valid. This could cause the program to overwrite unintended variables.

CWE-622.name: Improper Validation of Function Hook Arguments
CWE-622.description: The product adds hooks to user-accessible API functions, but it does not properly validate the arguments. This could lead to resultant vulnerabilities.

CWE-623.name: Unsafe ActiveX Control Marked Safe For Scripting
CWE-623.description: An ActiveX control is intended for restricted use, but it has been marked as safe-for-scripting.

CWE-626.name: Null Byte Interaction Error (Poison Null Byte)
CWE-626.description: The product does not properly handle null bytes or NUL characters when passing data between different representations or components.

CWE-627.name: Dynamic Variable Evaluation
CWE-627.description: In a language where the user can influence the name of a variable at runtime, if the variable names are not controlled, an attacker can read or write to arbitrary variables, or access arbitrary functions.

CWE-636.name: Not Failing Securely ('Failing Open')
CWE-636.description: When the product encounters an error condition or failure, its design requires it to fall back to a state that is less secure than other options that are available, such as selecting the weakest encryption algorithm or using the most permissive access control restrictions.

CWE-637.name: Unnecessary Complexity in Protection Mechanism (Not Using 'Economy of Mechanism')
CWE-637.description: The product uses a more complex mechanism than necessary, which could lead to resultant weaknesses when the mechanism is not correctly understood, modeled, configured, implemented, or used.

CWE-638.name: Not Using Complete Mediation
CWE-638.description: The product does not perform access checks on a resource every time the resource is accessed by an entity, which can create resultant weaknesses if that entity's rights or privileges change over time.

CWE-64.name: Windows Shortcut Following (.LNK)
CWE-64.description: The product, when opening a file or directory, does not sufficiently handle when the file is a Windows shortcut (.LNK) whose target is outside of the intended control sphere. This could allow an attacker to cause the product to operate on unauthorized files.

CWE-642.name: External Control of Critical State Data
CWE-642.description: The product stores security-critical state information about its users, or the product itself, in a location that is accessible to unauthorized actors.

CWE-643.name: Improper Neutralization of Data within XPath Expressions ('XPath Injection')
CWE-643.description: The product uses external input to dynamically construct an XPath expression used to retrieve data from an XML database, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes that input. This allows an attacker to control the structure of the query.

CWE-644.name: Improper Neutralization of HTTP Headers for Scripting Syntax
CWE-644.description: The product does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes web scripting syntax in HTTP headers that can be used by web browser components that can process raw headers, such as Flash.

CWE-646.name: Reliance on File Name or Extension of Externally-Supplied File
CWE-646.description: The product allows a file to be uploaded, but it relies on the file name or extension of the file to determine the appropriate behaviors. This could be used by attackers to cause the file to be misclassified and processed in a dangerous fashion.

CWE-647.name: Use of Non-Canonical URL Paths for Authorization Decisions
CWE-647.description: The product defines policy namespaces and makes authorization decisions based on the assumption that a URL is canonical. This can allow a non-canonical URL to bypass the authorization.

CWE-65.name: Windows Hard Link
CWE-65.description: The product, when opening a file or directory, does not sufficiently handle when the name is associated with a hard link to a target that is outside of the intended control sphere. This could allow an attacker to cause the product to operate on unauthorized files.

CWE-650.name: Trusting HTTP Permission Methods on the Server Side
CWE-650.description: The server contains a protection mechanism that assumes that any URI that is accessed using HTTP GET will not cause a state change to the associated resource. This might allow attackers to bypass intended access restrictions and conduct resource modification and deletion attacks, since some applications allow GET to modify state.

CWE-651.name: Exposure of WSDL File Containing Sensitive Information
CWE-651.description: The Web services architecture may require exposing a Web Service Definition Language (WSDL) file that contains information on the publicly accessible services and how callers of these services should interact with them (e.g. what parameters they expect and what types they return).

CWE-652.name: Improper Neutralization of Data within XQuery Expressions ('XQuery Injection')
CWE-652.description: The product uses external input to dynamically construct an XQuery expression used to retrieve data from an XML database, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes that input. This allows an attacker to control the structure of the query.

CWE-655.name: Insufficient Psychological Acceptability
CWE-655.description: The product has a protection mechanism that is too difficult or inconvenient to use, encouraging non-malicious users to disable or bypass the mechanism, whether by accident or on purpose.

CWE-657.name: Violation of Secure Design Principles
CWE-657.description: The product violates well-established principles for secure design.

CWE-662.name: Improper Synchronization
CWE-662.description: The product utilizes multiple threads, processes, components, or systems to allow temporary access to a shared resource that can only be exclusive to one process at a time, but it does not properly synchronize these actions, which might cause simultaneous accesses of this resource by multiple threads or processes.

CWE-664.name: Improper Control of a Resource Through its Lifetime
CWE-664.description: The product does not maintain or incorrectly maintains control over a resource throughout its lifetime of creation, use, and release.

CWE-665.name: Improper Initialization
CWE-665.description: The product does not initialize or incorrectly initializes a resource, which might leave the resource in an unexpected state when it is accessed or used.

CWE-666.name: Operation on Resource in Wrong Phase of Lifetime
CWE-666.description: The product performs an operation on a resource at the wrong phase of the resource's lifecycle, which can lead to unexpected behaviors.

CWE-667.name: Improper Locking
CWE-667.description: The product does not properly acquire or release a lock on a resource, leading to unexpected resource state changes and behaviors.

CWE-668.name: Exposure of Resource to Wrong Sphere
CWE-668.description: The product exposes a resource to the wrong control sphere, providing unintended actors with inappropriate access to the resource.

CWE-669.name: Incorrect Resource Transfer Between Spheres
CWE-669.description: The product does not properly transfer a resource/behavior to another sphere, or improperly imports a resource/behavior from another sphere, in a manner that provides unintended control over that resource.

CWE-67.name: Improper Handling of Windows Device Names
CWE-67.description: The product constructs pathnames from user input, but it does not handle or incorrectly handles a pathname containing a Windows device name such as AUX or CON. This typically leads to denial of service or an information exposure when the application attempts to process the pathname as a regular file.

CWE-670.name: Always-Incorrect Control Flow Implementation
CWE-670.description: The code contains a control flow path that does not reflect the algorithm that the path is intended to implement, leading to incorrect behavior any time this path is navigated.

CWE-671.name: Lack of Administrator Control over Security
CWE-671.description: The product uses security features in a way that prevents the product's administrator from tailoring security settings to reflect the environment in which the product is being used. This introduces resultant weaknesses or prevents it from operating at a level of security that is desired by the administrator.

CWE-672.name: Operation on a Resource after Expiration or Release
CWE-672.description: The product uses, accesses, or otherwise operates on a resource after that resource has been expired, released, or revoked.

CWE-673.name: External Influence of Sphere Definition
CWE-673.description: The product does not prevent the definition of control spheres from external actors.

CWE-674.name: Uncontrolled Recursion
CWE-674.description: The product does not properly control the amount of recursion that takes place, consuming excessive resources, such as allocated memory or the program stack.

CWE-675.name: Multiple Operations on Resource in Single-Operation Context
CWE-675.description: The product performs the same operation on a resource two or more times, when the operation should only be applied once.

CWE-680.name: Integer Overflow to Buffer Overflow
CWE-680.description: The product performs a calculation to determine how much memory to allocate, but an integer overflow can occur that causes less memory to be allocated than expected, leading to a buffer overflow.

CWE-682.name: Incorrect Calculation
CWE-682.description: The product performs a calculation that generates incorrect or unintended results that are later used in security-critical decisions or resource management.

CWE-683.name: Function Call With Incorrect Order of Arguments
CWE-683.description: The product calls a function, procedure, or routine, but the caller specifies the arguments in an incorrect order, leading to resultant weaknesses.

CWE-684.name: Incorrect Provision of Specified Functionality
CWE-684.description: The code does not function according to its published specifications, potentially leading to incorrect usage.

CWE-685.name: Function Call With Incorrect Number of Arguments
CWE-685.description: The product calls a function, procedure, or routine, but the caller specifies too many arguments, or too few arguments, which may lead to undefined behavior and resultant weaknesses.

CWE-686.name: Function Call With Incorrect Argument Type
CWE-686.description: The product calls a function, procedure, or routine, but the caller specifies an argument that is the wrong data type, which may lead to resultant weaknesses.

CWE-687.name: Function Call With Incorrectly Specified Argument Value
CWE-687.description: The product calls a function, procedure, or routine, but the caller specifies an argument that contains the wrong value, which may lead to resultant weaknesses.

CWE-688.name: Function Call With Incorrect Variable or Reference as Argument
CWE-688.description: The product calls a function, procedure, or routine, but the caller specifies the wrong variable or reference as one of the arguments, which may lead to undefined behavior and resultant weaknesses.

CWE-689.name: Permission Race Condition During Resource Copy
CWE-689.description: The product, while copying or cloning a resource, does not set the resource's permissions or access control until the copy is complete, leaving the resource exposed to other spheres while the copy is taking place.

CWE-69.name: Improper Handling of Windows ::DATA Alternate Data Stream
CWE-69.description: The product does not properly prevent access to, or detect usage of, alternate data streams (ADS).

CWE-690.name: Unchecked Return Value to NULL Pointer Dereference
CWE-690.description: The product does not check for an error after calling a function that can return with a NULL pointer if the function fails, which leads to a resultant NULL pointer dereference.

CWE-691.name: Insufficient Control Flow Management
CWE-691.description: The code does not sufficiently manage its control flow during execution, creating conditions in which the control flow can be modified in unexpected ways.

CWE-692.name: Incomplete Denylist to Cross-Site Scripting
CWE-692.description: The product uses a denylist-based protection mechanism to defend against XSS attacks, but the denylist is incomplete, allowing XSS variants to succeed.

CWE-693.name: Protection Mechanism Failure
CWE-693.description: The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product.

CWE-696.name: Incorrect Behavior Order
CWE-696.description: The product performs multiple related behaviors, but the behaviors are performed in the wrong order in ways that may produce resultant weaknesses.

CWE-697.name: Incorrect Comparison
CWE-697.description: The product compares two entities in a security-relevant context, but the comparison is incorrect.

CWE-7.name: J2EE Misconfiguration: Missing Custom Error Page
CWE-7.description: The default error page of a web application should not display sensitive information about the product.

CWE-703.name: Improper Check or Handling of Exceptional Conditions
CWE-703.description: The product does not properly anticipate or handle exceptional conditions that rarely occur during normal operation of the product.

CWE-704.name: Incorrect Type Conversion or Cast
CWE-704.description: The product does not correctly convert an object, resource, or structure from one type to a different type.

CWE-705.name: Incorrect Control Flow Scoping
CWE-705.description: The product does not properly return control flow to the proper location after it has completed a task or detected an unusual condition.

CWE-706.name: Use of Incorrectly-Resolved Name or Reference
CWE-706.description: The product uses a name or reference to access a resource, but the name/reference resolves to a resource that is outside of the intended control sphere.

CWE-707.name: Improper Neutralization
CWE-707.description: The product does not ensure or incorrectly ensures that structured messages or data are well-formed and that certain security properties are met before being read from an upstream component or sent to a downstream component.

CWE-710.name: Improper Adherence to Coding Standards
CWE-710.description: The product does not follow certain coding rules for development, which can lead to resultant weaknesses or increase the severity of the associated vulnerabilities.

CWE-72.name: Improper Handling of Apple HFS+ Alternate Data Stream Path
CWE-72.description: The product does not properly handle special paths that may identify the data or resource fork of a file on the HFS+ file system.

CWE-732.name: Incorrect Permission Assignment for Critical Resource
CWE-732.description: The product specifies permissions for a security-critical resource in a way that allows that resource to be read or modified by unintended actors.

CWE-74.name: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements in Output Used by a Downstream Component ('Injection')
CWE-74.description: The product constructs all or part of a command, data structure, or record using externally-influenced input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could modify how it is parsed or interpreted when it is sent to a downstream component.

CWE-75.name: Failure to Sanitize Special Elements into a Different Plane (Special Element Injection)
CWE-75.description: The product does not adequately filter user-controlled input for special elements with control implications.

CWE-754.name: Improper Check for Unusual or Exceptional Conditions
CWE-754.description: The product does not check or incorrectly checks for unusual or exceptional conditions that are not expected to occur frequently during day to day operation of the product.

CWE-755.name: Improper Handling of Exceptional Conditions
CWE-755.description: The product does not handle or incorrectly handles an exceptional condition.

CWE-757.name: Selection of Less-Secure Algorithm During Negotiation ('Algorithm Downgrade')
CWE-757.description: A protocol or its implementation supports interaction between multiple actors and allows those actors to negotiate which algorithm should be used as a protection mechanism such as encryption or authentication, but it does not select the strongest algorithm that is available to both parties.

CWE-758.name: Reliance on Undefined, Unspecified, or Implementation-Defined Behavior
CWE-758.description: The product uses an API function, data structure, or other entity in a way that relies on properties that are not always guaranteed to hold for that entity.

CWE-759.name: Use of a One-Way Hash without a Salt
CWE-759.description: The product uses a one-way cryptographic hash against an input that should not be reversible, such as a password, but the product does not also use a salt as part of the input.

CWE-760.name: Use of a One-Way Hash with a Predictable Salt
CWE-760.description: The product uses a one-way cryptographic hash against an input that should not be reversible, such as a password, but the product uses a predictable salt as part of the input.

CWE-761.name: Free of Pointer not at Start of Buffer
CWE-761.description: The product calls free() on a pointer to a memory resource that was allocated on the heap, but the pointer is not at the start of the buffer.

CWE-762.name: Mismatched Memory Management Routines
CWE-762.description: The product attempts to return a memory resource to the system, but it calls a release function that is not compatible with the function that was originally used to allocate that resource.

CWE-768.name: Incorrect Short Circuit Evaluation
CWE-768.description: The product contains a conditional statement with multiple logical expressions in which one of the non-leading expressions may produce side effects. This may lead to an unexpected state in the program after the execution of the conditional, because short-circuiting logic may prevent the side effects from occurring.

CWE-77.name: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in a Command ('Command Injection')
CWE-77.description: The product constructs all or part of a command using externally-influenced input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could modify the intended command when it is sent to a downstream component.

CWE-773.name: Missing Reference to Active File Descriptor or Handle
CWE-773.description: The product does not properly maintain references to a file descriptor or handle, which prevents that file descriptor/handle from being reclaimed.

CWE-774.name: Allocation of File Descriptors or Handles Without Limits or Throttling
CWE-774.description: The product allocates file descriptors or handles on behalf of an actor without imposing any restrictions on how many descriptors can be allocated, in violation of the intended security policy for that actor.

CWE-775.name: Missing Release of File Descriptor or Handle after Effective Lifetime
CWE-775.description: The product does not release a file descriptor or handle after its effective lifetime has ended, i.e., after the file descriptor/handle is no longer needed.

CWE-777.name: Regular Expression without Anchors
CWE-777.description: The product uses a regular expression to perform neutralization, but the regular expression is not anchored and may allow malicious or malformed data to slip through.

CWE-780.name: Use of RSA Algorithm without OAEP
CWE-780.description: The product uses the RSA algorithm but does not incorporate Optimal Asymmetric Encryption Padding (OAEP), which might weaken the encryption.

CWE-781.name: Improper Address Validation in IOCTL with METHOD_NEITHER I/O Control Code
CWE-781.description: The product defines an IOCTL that uses METHOD_NEITHER for I/O, but it does not validate or incorrectly validates the addresses that are provided.

CWE-782.name: Exposed IOCTL with Insufficient Access Control
CWE-782.description: The product implements an IOCTL with functionality that should be restricted, but it does not properly enforce access control for the IOCTL.

CWE-784.name: Reliance on Cookies without Validation and Integrity Checking in a Security Decision
CWE-784.description: The product uses a protection mechanism that relies on the existence or values of a cookie, but it does not properly ensure that the cookie is valid for the associated user.

CWE-785.name: Use of Path Manipulation Function without Maximum-sized Buffer
CWE-785.description: The product invokes a function for normalizing paths or file names, but it provides an output buffer that is smaller than the maximum possible size, such as PATH_MAX.

CWE-789.name: Memory Allocation with Excessive Size Value
CWE-789.description: The product allocates memory based on an untrusted, large size value, but it does not ensure that the size is within expected limits, allowing arbitrary amounts of memory to be allocated.

CWE-790.name: Improper Filtering of Special Elements
CWE-790.description: The product receives data from an upstream component, but does not filter or incorrectly filters special elements before sending it to a downstream component.

CWE-792.name: Incomplete Filtering of One or More Instances of Special Elements
CWE-792.description: The product receives data from an upstream component, but does not completely filter one or more instances of special elements before sending it to a downstream component.

CWE-793.name: Only Filtering One Instance of a Special Element
CWE-793.description: The product receives data from an upstream component, but only filters a single instance of a special element before sending it to a downstream component.

CWE-794.name: Incomplete Filtering of Multiple Instances of Special Elements
CWE-794.description: The product receives data from an upstream component, but does not filter all instances of a special element before sending it to a downstream component.

CWE-795.name: Only Filtering Special Elements at a Specified Location
CWE-795.description: The product receives data from an upstream component, but only accounts for special elements at a specified location, thereby missing remaining special elements that may exist before sending it to a downstream component.

CWE-796.name: Only Filtering Special Elements Relative to a Marker
CWE-796.description: The product receives data from an upstream component, but only accounts for special elements positioned relative to a marker (e.g. "at the beginning/end of a string; the second argument"), thereby missing remaining special elements that may exist before sending it to a downstream component.

CWE-797.name: Only Filtering Special Elements at an Absolute Position
CWE-797.description: The product receives data from an upstream component, but only accounts for special elements at an absolute position (e.g. "byte number 10"), thereby missing remaining special elements that may exist before sending it to a downstream component.

CWE-799.name: Improper Control of Interaction Frequency
CWE-799.description: The product does not properly limit the number or frequency of interactions that it has with an actor, such as the number of incoming requests.

CWE-8.name: J2EE Misconfiguration: Entity Bean Declared Remote
CWE-8.description: When an application exposes a remote interface for an entity bean, it might also expose methods that get or set the bean's data. These methods could be leveraged to read sensitive information, or to change data in ways that violate the application's expectations, potentially leading to other vulnerabilities.

CWE-80.name: Improper Neutralization of Script-Related HTML Tags in a Web Page (Basic XSS)
CWE-80.description: The product receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special characters such as "", and "&" that could be interpreted as web-scripting elements when they are sent to a downstream component that processes web pages.

CWE-806.name: Buffer Access Using Size of Source Buffer
CWE-806.description: The product uses the size of a source buffer when reading from or writing to a destination buffer, which may cause it to access memory that is outside of the bounds of the buffer.

CWE-81.name: Improper Neutralization of Script in an Error Message Web Page
CWE-81.description: The product receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special characters that could be interpreted as web-scripting elements when they are sent to an error page.

CWE-82.name: Improper Neutralization of Script in Attributes of IMG Tags in a Web Page
CWE-82.description: The web application does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes scripting elements within attributes of HTML IMG tags, such as the src attribute.

CWE-827.name: Improper Control of Document Type Definition
CWE-827.description: The product does not restrict a reference to a Document Type Definition (DTD) to the intended control sphere. This might allow attackers to reference arbitrary DTDs, possibly causing the product to expose files, consume excessive system resources, or execute arbitrary http requests on behalf of the attacker.

CWE-828.name: Signal Handler with Functionality that is not Asynchronous-Safe
CWE-828.description: The product defines a signal handler that contains code sequences that are not asynchronous-safe, i.e., the functionality is not reentrant, or it can be interrupted.

CWE-83.name: Improper Neutralization of Script in Attributes in a Web Page
CWE-83.description: The product does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes "javascript:" or other URIs from dangerous attributes within tags, such as onmouseover, onload, onerror, or style.

CWE-830.name: Inclusion of Web Functionality from an Untrusted Source
CWE-830.description: The product includes web functionality (such as a web widget) from another domain, which causes it to operate within the domain of the product, potentially granting total access and control of the product to the untrusted source.

CWE-831.name: Signal Handler Function Associated with Multiple Signals
CWE-831.description: The product defines a function that is used as a handler for more than one signal.

CWE-834.name: Excessive Iteration
CWE-834.description: The product performs an iteration or loop without sufficiently limiting the number of times that the loop is executed.

CWE-84.name: Improper Neutralization of Encoded URI Schemes in a Web Page
CWE-84.description: The web application improperly neutralizes user-controlled input for executable script disguised with URI encodings.

CWE-85.name: Doubled Character XSS Manipulations
CWE-85.description: The web application does not filter user-controlled input for executable script disguised using doubling of the involved characters.

CWE-86.name: Improper Neutralization of Invalid Characters in Identifiers in Web Pages
CWE-86.description: The product does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes invalid characters or byte sequences in the middle of tag names, URI schemes, and other identifiers.

CWE-862.name: Missing Authorization
CWE-862.description: The product does not perform an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

CWE-863.name: Incorrect Authorization
CWE-863.description: The product performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action, but it does not correctly perform the check.

CWE-87.name: Improper Neutralization of Alternate XSS Syntax
CWE-87.description: The product does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes user-controlled input for alternate script syntax.

CWE-9.name: J2EE Misconfiguration: Weak Access Permissions for EJB Methods
CWE-9.description: If elevated access rights are assigned to EJB methods, then an attacker can take advantage of the permissions to exploit the product.

CWE-912.name: Hidden Functionality
CWE-912.description: The product contains functionality that is not documented, not part of the specification, and not accessible through an interface or command sequence that is obvious to the product's users or administrators.

CWE-913.name: Improper Control of Dynamically-Managed Code Resources
CWE-913.description: The product does not properly restrict reading from or writing to dynamically-managed code resources such as variables, objects, classes, attributes, functions, or executable instructions or statements.

CWE-922.name: Insecure Storage of Sensitive Information
CWE-922.description: The product stores sensitive information without properly limiting read or write access by unauthorized actors.

CWE-923.name: Improper Restriction of Communication Channel to Intended Endpoints
CWE-923.description: The product establishes a communication channel to (or from) an endpoint for privileged or protected operations, but it does not properly ensure that it is communicating with the correct endpoint.

CWE-925.name: Improper Verification of Intent by Broadcast Receiver
CWE-925.description: The Android application uses a Broadcast Receiver that receives an Intent but does not properly verify that the Intent came from an authorized source.

CWE-926.name: Improper Export of Android Application Components
CWE-926.description: The Android application exports a component for use by other applications, but does not properly restrict which applications can launch the component or access the data it contains.

CWE-927.name: Use of Implicit Intent for Sensitive Communication
CWE-927.description: The Android application uses an implicit intent for transmitting sensitive data to other applications.

CWE-942.name: Permissive Cross-domain Security Policy with Untrusted Domains
CWE-942.description: The product uses a web-client protection mechanism such as a Content Security Policy (CSP) or cross-domain policy file, but the policy includes untrusted domains with which the web client is allowed to communicate.

CWE-943.name: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements in Data Query Logic
CWE-943.description: The product generates a query intended to access or manipulate data in a data store such as a database, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that can modify the intended logic of the query.

CWE-95.name: Improper Neutralization of Directives in Dynamically Evaluated Code ('Eval Injection')
CWE-95.description: The product receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes code syntax before using the input in a dynamic evaluation call (e.g. "eval").

CWE-96.name: Improper Neutralization of Directives in Statically Saved Code ('Static Code Injection')
CWE-96.description: The product receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes code syntax before inserting the input into an executable resource, such as a library, configuration file, or template.

CWE-97.name: Improper Neutralization of Server-Side Includes (SSI) Within a Web Page
CWE-97.description: The product generates a web page, but does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes user-controllable input that could be interpreted as a server-side include (SSI) directive.

CWE-98.name: Improper Control of Filename for Include/Require Statement in PHP Program ('PHP Remote File Inclusion')
CWE-98.description: The PHP application receives input from an upstream component, but it does not restrict or incorrectly restricts the input before its usage in "require," "include," or similar functions.

CWE-99.name: Improper Control of Resource Identifiers ('Resource Injection')
CWE-99.description: The product receives input from an upstream component, but it does not restrict or incorrectly restricts the input before it is used as an identifier for a resource that may be outside the intended sphere of control.

1198.name: Privilege Separation and Access Control Issues
